contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox prepared food | name = Zōni | image = [[File:Zoni by yoppy.jpg|250px]] | caption = | alternate_name = | country = [[Japan]] | region = | creator = | course = | type = [[Soup]] | served = | main_ingredient = [[Mochi (food)|mochi]] rice cakes | variations = | calories = | other = }} [[File:Zoni by atmo in Nagoya, with rice cake.jpg|thumb|180px|right|Eating grilled ''mochi'' from ''zōni.'']] [[File:Hakata zoni.jpeg|thumbnail|Hakata ''zōni'']] {{nihongo|'''Zōni'''|雑煮}}, often with the [[Honorific speech in Japanese|honorific]] "o-" as ''o-zōni'', is a Japanese [[soup]] containing ''[[Mochi (food)|mochi]]'' rice cakes.<ref name="dijitaru">{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Dijitaru daijisen | title = 美保湾 (Miho-wan) | url = http://rekishi.jkn21.com/| accessdate = 2012-05-20 | year = 2012 | publisher = Shogakukan | location = Tokyo | language = Japanese}}</ref> The dish is strongly associated with the [[Japanese New Year]] and its tradition of ''[[osechi]]'' ceremonial foods. Zōni is considered the most [[auspicious]] of the dishes eaten on [[New Year's Day]].<ref name="enc">{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Encyclopedia of Japan | title = Zōni | url = http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ | accessdate = 2012-05-22 | year = 2012 | publisher = Shogakukan | location = Tokyo}}</ref> The preparation of zōni varies both by household and region.<ref name="dijitaru"/> ==Etymology== Zōni is written in the [[Japanese language]] using two ''[[kanji]]'' characters. The first, {{linktext|雑}} means "miscellaneous" or "mixed", and the second, {{linktext|煮}}, means "[[simmering|simmer]]" or "boil". ==Origin== It is said that ''zōni'' finds its roots in [[samurai]] society cuisine. It is thought to be a meal that was cooked during field battles, boiled together with ''mochi,'' [[vegetable]]s and [[dried food]]s, among other ingredients. It is also generally believed that this original meal, at first exclusive to samurai, eventually became a [[staple food]] of the common people. Zōni was first served as part of a full-course dinner (''[[honzen ryori|honzen ryōri]]''), and thus is thought to have been a considerably important meal to samurai. The tradition of eating ''zōni'' on New Year's Day dates to the end of the [[Muromachi period]] (1336–1573). The dish was offered to the gods in a ceremony on [[New Year's Eve]].<ref name="kokugo">{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Nihon Kokugo Daijiten | title = Tone-gawa | url = http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ | accessdate = 2012-05-22 | year = 2012 | publisher = Shogakukan | location = Tokyo | language = Japanese}}</ref> ==Variations== ===Stock=== Zōni has numerous regional variations in [[Japan]]. In the [[Kantō region]] zōni consists of a clear soup called ''[[sumashi-jiru]]'' which is flavoured with ''[[dashi]]'', a [[Stock (food)|stock]] made from flakes of dried [[skipjack tuna|bonito]] and/or [[kombu]], and [[soy sauce]]. In the [[Kansai region]], [[Shikoku]], and [[Kyushu]] zōni is generally made with a stock of white [[miso]].<ref name="kokugo"/> ===Mochi=== The preparation of the ''mochi'' for the dish also varies by region. In the Kantō region the ''mochi'' is cut into squares and grilled before being added to the stock. In the Kansai region a round, boiled mochi is preferred.<ref name="enc"/> In some areas [[taro]] or [[tofu]] is used instead of mochi. This type of zōni is found on some islands or mountainous areas where rice is not grown to a large extent. ===Additions=== Common additions to the soup include [[chicken]], [[fish (food)|fish]] or [[meatball]]s; [[leafy vegetable]]s such as ''[[komatsuna]]'' or [[spinach]]; ''[[mitsuba]]'' (a Japanese [[herb]] similar to [[parsley]]); ''[[kamaboko]]'' such as ''naruto'' and carrot flakes for colour;<ref name="enc"/> and flakes of ''[[yuzu]]'' peel for its citrus fragrance. Regional specialties are often added. A sprinkle of seven-spice chili flakes (''[[shichimi togarashi|shichimi]]'') is sometimes added at the table. ==See also== {{commons category|Zoni}} *[[Japanese New Year]] *[[Tteok guk]], a similar soup eaten in Korea on New Year's Day ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zoni}} [[Category:Japanese soups and stews]] [[Category:Holiday foods]]
